@graph.name: How to Calculate Average Order Value Manually
@graph.description: Manual calculation method for AOV using the standard formula

step.name: Gather Sales Data
step.text: Collect total sales revenue (net sales after discounts, before shipping and taxes)

step.name: Count Total Orders
step.text: Determine the total number of orders for the same period

step.name: Apply Formula
step.text: Divide Total Sales Revenue by Total Number of Orders

step.name: Example Calculation
step.text: If your store did $50,000 in sales from 1,000 orders: $50,000 ÷ 1,000 = $50 AOV

mainEntity.name: Which Shopify report is best for getting the raw numbers for my AOV calculation?

acceptedAnswer.text: The 'Sales over time' report in your Shopify Analytics is the gold standard. It gives you the two numbers you need: total sales and the total number of orders for any given period. This is the cleanest source for doing any manual or segmented calculations.

mainEntity.name: Beyond AOV, what other metrics give the best context on customer value?

acceptedAnswer.text: You absolutely have to look at Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) and Purchase Frequency. AOV tells you what a customer spends now, but CLV tells you what they're worth over their entire relationship with your brand. A customer with a slightly lower AOV but a much higher purchase frequency might actually be more valuable in the long run. These three metrics together paint a full picture.

mainEntity.name: How does segmenting my customers actually change my AOV insights?

acceptedAnswer.text: Segmenting is everything. A blended, store-wide AOV might be $80. But when you segment, you might find that new customers have an AOV of $60 while returning customers have an AOV of $110. That's not just a data point; it's a massive strategic insight. It tells you that your efforts should focus on turning new customers into repeat buyers, because that's where the real value is. Without segmentation, that crucial detail is completely hidden.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Average Order Value
hasDefinedTerm.description: The average dollar amount a customer spends every time they place an order on your store over a specific period. Calculated as Total Sales Revenue divided by Total Number of Orders.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Customer Lifetime Value
hasDefinedTerm.description: The total long-term value of a customer over their entire relationship with your brand, calculated as AOV × Purchase Frequency × Customer Lifespan.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Conversion Rate
hasDefinedTerm.description: The percentage of website visitors who complete a desired action, such as making a purchase.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Product Bundling
hasDefinedTerm.description: A marketing strategy where related products are grouped together and sold as a single package, usually at a slight discount.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Upselling
hasDefinedTerm.description: A sales technique where customers are persuaded to purchase a more expensive version of a product they're considering.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Cross-selling
hasDefinedTerm.description: A sales technique where customers are offered related or complementary products to their original purchase.
